qas.question: Do fluorescent lights have a higher or lower luminous efficiency than incandescents?
How can luminescent light sources be modified to resemble the appearance of incandescents?

answers.text: By careful selection of which electron energy level transitions are used, and fluorescent coatings which modify the spectral distribution

qas.question: Why are luminescent light sources not ideal for photography?

answers.text: Due to the discrete spectral lines rather than a continuous spectrum

qas.question: Which lights have lower luminous efficiency?
Which devices do not produce light by luminescence?
What lamps produce prominent spectral lines and have a broad "tail" of visible infrared emissions?

plausible_answers.text: Due to the discrete spectral lines rather than a continuous spectrum

qas.question: Why are luminescent light sources ideal for photography?

context: There are many non-incandescent light sources, such as the <b3_0><b4_0><b5_0>fluorescent<b5_0/><b4_0/> lamp<b3_0/>, high-intensity discharge lamps and LED lamps, which have <a0_0>higher<a0_0/> luminous efficiency, and some have been designed to be retrofitted in fixtures for incandescent lights. These devices produce light by luminescence. These lamps produce discrete spectral lines and do not have the broad "tail" of invisible infrared emissions. <a1_0>By careful selection of which electron energy level transitions are used, and fluorescent coatings which modify the spectral distribution<a1_0/>, the spectrum emitted can be tuned to mimic the appearance of incandescent sources, or other different color temperatures of white light. <a2_0><b6_0>Due to the discrete spectral lines rather than a continuous spectrum<b6_0/><a2_0/>, the light is not ideal for applications such as photography and cinematography.
